ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was mostly conducted as a live virtual lecture, but because I was on campus it also sometimes had a component of in-person performance/practice.
in-person rehearsals
Some in-person lessons and rehearsals
Recording, musical reherseal
Virtual lectures, in-person/remote rehearsals and recordings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about Renaissance music, rhetorical techniques, and various instruments.

Covers the basic elements of music theory that were most relevant in early music, as well as some history of musicians, composers, and important developments to accompany the pieces we play.  Mostly, you gain confidence with playing this style of music, and you get out of class whatever you want to put in.
Was able to improve music playing, interpreting Early Music, intervals, and more.

I developed a lot of knowledge about the history and practices of early music from different time periods. We explored many different styles and composers, so I think I gained a good general understanding and skills to identify and best reproduce this type of music.
Performance of early music, understanding of the importance of rhetoric.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: great class!
Weaknesses: none
Grant is great, TA was very nice this semester as well. And Philippa for the recorders is always amazing!

I found the lectures engaging and enjoyed practising my parts for our pieces. It was also very rewarding to see the finished product of our work for the semester at our listening sessions. In terms of weaknesses, it was difficult to successfully record our parts online. Because the course is so practical, I think it has unfortunately been seriously impacted by the move to virtual learning. Nevertheless, I enjoyed the course and still managed to improve my technique throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think we did the best we could do given the present situation. The class recordings turned out great.
Sometimes difficult to find space to practice flexibly
use of screen share for performances was very helpful. Recording at-home also seemed to work decently well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Absolutely! I got to learn how to play a whole new instrument, and the music we played sounded so nice.
Absolutely! The professor is so fun and as long as you enjoy playing music and learning tidbits of history alongside, you'll enjoy this class.

Yes! This is a lovely class with so many interesting elements. Though the online format was challenging for a performance-based class, I thought he did a good job of maintaining the typical lectures and learning lots of new music. The recordings took a bit of doing, certainly, but they generally came together well.
Definitely, no annoying grunt work involved, get to learn and improve your musical abilities
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. It was very engaging and Professor Herreid is a great instructor.
Yes, if they have a history of ensemble experience or a true interest in early music.

extras.title:
MUSI 240 01
        The Performance of Early Music
